title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" introduces a new section for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" introduces a new section for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. If a party alleges misconduct, bias, departure from procedure, or exceeding of powers by a panel within 30 days of publication, the court of international trade may review the determination. If a party believes that a binational panel decision has been affected by misconduct or errors, they can appeal to the United States Court of International Trade for review under the Tariff Act of 1930. The court will assess the legal and factual analysis of the panel's decision to determine if any misconduct or errors occurred. The United States Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals regarding binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. The court will vacate the original decision if misconduct or errors are established, otherwise, it will affirm the decision. Decisions made by the court are binding on the parties involved. The United States Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals regarding binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. The court will vacate the original decision if misconduct or errors are established, otherwise, it will affirm the decision. Decisions made by the court are binding on the parties involved. International Trade determinations are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee under paragraph 13 of article 1904. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. A conforming amendment is made to the North American Free Trade Implementation Act. The United States Court of International Trade has jurisdiction over appeals on binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. Decisions made by the court are binding on the parties involved. International Trade determinations are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA. The amendments also specify exceptions for certain determinations and clarify clauses within the Act. The Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include final determinations from NAFTA binational panels. Amendments clarify clauses and exceptions within the Act, including a new provision for review requests under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act will apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA article 1904 published in the Federal Register after the enactment date of this Act.
